qas.question: Around what time did materialism become part of Ancient Indian philosophy?
At that time, who helped develop materialism?

answers.text: Ajita Kesakambali, Payasi, Kanada, and the proponents of the Cārvāka school of philosophy

qas.question: Between what years did the school advance atomism?
Around what time did Ancient Indian philosophy reject materialism?

plausible_answers.text: Ajita Kesakambali, Payasi, Kanada, and the proponents of the Cārvāka school of philosophy

qas.question: At that time, who rejected the idea of materialism?
What school did not teach atomism?
What tradition did the Jaina school stop?

context: In Ancient Indian philosophy, materialism developed around <a0_0><b4_0>600 BC<b4_0/><a0_0/> with the works of <a1_0><b5_0>Ajita Kesakambali, Payasi, Kanada, and the proponents of the Cārvāka school of philosophy<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Kanada became one of the early proponents of atomism. <b6_0>The <a2_0>Nyaya–Vaisesika school<b6_0/><a2_0/> (<a3_0>600 BC - 100 BC<a3_0/>) developed one of the earliest forms of atomism, though their proofs of God and their positing that the consciousness was not material precludes labelling them as materialists. Buddhist atomism and the Jaina school continued the <b7_0><b8_0>atomic<b8_0/><b7_0/> tradition.
